title: Divisibility-Free Property
content:
A set A is **divisibility-free** if for all distinct a, b, c in A with a < b and a < c, we have a does NOT divide (b + c).

This constraint prevents small elements from 'capturing' sums of larger elements.
mathContext: The condition requires checking all triples (a,b,c) with a being the smallest. This is a multiplicative constraint on an additive structure.

title: Counting Function
content: The **counting function** |A ∩ {1,...,N}| measures how many elements of A are at most N. The growth rate of this function is the central question.

title: Powers of 2 Example
content:
The set {2, 4, 8, 16, ...} = {2^k : k >= 1} is divisibility-free.

**Proof sketch:** If 2^a | (2^b + 2^c) with a < b,c, then 2^a divides 2^min(b,c) * (1 + 2^|b-c|). But 1 + 2^|b-c| is odd, so we need 2^a | 2^min(b,c), meaning a <= min(b,c). Since a < b and a < c, we have a < min(b,c), contradiction.

title: Prime Squares mod 4
content: The squares of primes p = 3 (mod 4) form a large divisibility-free set. This construction achieves |A ∩ {1,...,N}| / √N * log N > 0.

title: Density Zero
content: A set has **density 0** if |A ∩ {1,...,N}| / N tends to 0 as N approaches infinity. This means the set becomes increasingly sparse relative to all integers.

title: Erdos-Sarkozy (1970)
content:
**Fundamental Result:** Every infinite divisibility-free set has density 0.

This rules out sets with positive density but leaves open how slowly the density can decay. The three questions probe this decay rate.

title: √N Density
content: A set has **positive √N density** if liminf |A ∩ {1,...,N}| / √N > 0. This is the threshold asked about in Question 1.

title: Question 1 (OPEN)
content:
**Can a divisibility-free set achieve √N density?**

No construction has achieved this, but no proof rules it out. The gap between best constructions and this threshold remains.

title: Elsholtz-Planitzer (2017)
content:
**Best Known Construction:** There exists a divisibility-free set with

|A ∩ {1,...,N}| >= √N / (√log N * (log log N)²)

This is tantalizingly close to √N but falls short by logarithmic factors.

title: Question 2 (OPEN)
content:
**Must divisibility-free sets be sparse infinitely often?**

Is there c > 0 such that |A ∩ {1,...,N}| < N^(1-c) for infinitely many N? This asks if the set must dip below polynomial growth infinitely often.

title: Reciprocal Sum
content: The **reciprocal sum** is the sum of 1/n over all n in A. Convergence of this sum implies the set is quite sparse (e.g., primes have divergent reciprocal sum).

title: Question 3 (OPEN)
content:
**Must the reciprocal sum converge?**

This is the strongest sparseness condition. If true, it would imply positive answers to Q1 and Q2. The sum of 1/n over squares converges (pi²/6), so this is plausible.

title: Pairwise Coprime
content: A set is **pairwise coprime** if any two distinct elements share no common factor > 1. This is a strong constraint that enables better bounds.

title: Schoen-Baier Bound
content:
**Coprime Case:** If A is both divisibility-free and pairwise coprime, then

|A ∩ {1,...,N}| = O(N^(2/3) / log N)

Proved by Schoen (2001) and Baier (2004) using sieve methods.

title: Combined Problem Statement
content: **Erdos Problem #12** combines all three questions. Resolving any one would be a significant advance. The logical structure is: Q3 implies Q2 implies (negation of Q1).
